info.headline: Flood Advisory issued September 05 at 7:37AM EDT until September 05 at 3:15PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 715 PM EDT THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Portions of western North Carolina and upstate South Carolina, including the following counties, in western North Carolina, Transylvania. In upstate South Carolina, Greenville, Oconee and Pickens. * WHEN...Until 715 PM EDT Monday. * IMPACTS...Nuisance to Minor flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams is likely, including farmland, boat-access areas, greenways, parks, campgrounds, low-water crossings, and flood-prone roadways. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 720 AM EDT, Multiple rounds of heavy rain have impacted the region since Sunday. Over the past 6 hours, doppler radar indicated about 1-3 inches of new rainfall has occurred over saturated soils, causing excessive runoff into area streams. Nuisance to Minor flooding will continue to develop in isolated to scattered locations across the Advisory area through this morning hours. Rapid rises on several streams, including the French Broad from Rosman to Brevard to Blantyre, the Little River from Cedar Mountain to Penrose, and the headwaters of the Toxaway River in and near Gorges State Park as well as the headwaters of the South Saluda River in and around Table Rock State Park, will result in flooding of adjacent low-lying areas. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1.5 inches are expected over the area early this morning. This additional rainfall may exacerbate ongoing flooding and cause stream levels to continue rising. Additional rounds of rainfall are expected later today and this may cause new flash flooding concerns. Please stay weather aware and prepare to seek higher ground should a Flash Flood Warning be issued. - Some locations that may experience flooding include... Brevard, Slater-Marietta, Rosman, Table Rock State Park, Jocassee Gorges, Gorges State Park, Caesars Head State Park, Dupont State Forest, Keowee Toxaway State Park, Looking Glass, Jones Gap State Park, Devils Fork State Park, Rocky Bottom, Connestee, Sunset and Cedar Mountain.
info.instruction: In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
